fcm Module¶

fuzzy.old.fcm.analyze_msm(t_matrix, centroids, desc, neigen=4, show=False)¶

Analyze a particular msm.

Right now, it does this by printing eigenvalues and optionally plotting eigenvectors.

fuzzy.old.fcm.build_new(centroids, trajs, fuzziness, dist, soft=True, neigen=4, show=False, desc=None)¶

Build an MSM from points and centroids.

First this function generates membership vectors.

if soft is False, ‘Quantize’ the membership vectors to mirror the hard clustering case, else use the fuzzy nature of the clusters in building the MSM.

fuzzy.old.fcm.calculate_centroid(i, points, memberships, fuzziness)¶

Calculates the centroid V_i

Calculates k centroids relative to points and their memberships.

fuzzy.old.fcm.calculate_membership(centroid_i, point_i, points, centroids, fuzziness, dist)¶

Calculate the membership u_ij given data points and centroids.

fuzzy.old.fcm.calculate_memberships(points, centroids, fuzziness, dist)¶

Calculate memberships of points relative to centroids.

Use classic clustering methods.

Run through various schemes for comparison.

Do very classic schemes and compare to mixture modelling.

Do fuzzy clustering.

fuzzy.old.fcm.fcm_using_classic_clusters(trajs_old, trajs_new, n_clusters, n_medoid_iters, metric, dim=2, fuzziness=2.0, dist=<function euclidean_distance at 0x4c63c80>, soft=True, show=False, desc=None)¶

fuzzy.old.fcm.generate_test_points(n_points_per=100, dim=2, n_centers=3, bounds=None, variance=0.6)¶

Generate random points over the muller potential.

fuzzy.old.fcm.get_giant_state_list(centroids, trajs, fuzziness, dist, soft=True, lag_time=1)¶

Get a matrix of pairs of membership vectors.

The resulting matrix has dimension n_points x 2 x n_clusters. The second index is either 0 or 1 and corresponds to ‘from’ or ‘to’ membership vectors.

fuzzy.old.fcm.get_hard_state_list(centroids, traj, fuzziness, dist)¶

From a trajectory and a clustering scheme, get the list of states through which the trajectory traverses in a ‘hard’ clustering scheme.

This function uses the cluster of highest membership to describe state transitions.

This function returns both a classic list of state indexes as well as a list of membership vectors that has been ‘hardened’ to be of the form [0, ..., 0, 1, 0, ..., 0].

fuzzy.old.fcm.get_soft_state_list(centroids, traj, fuzziness, dist)¶

From a trajectory and a clustering scheme, get the list of membership vectors through which the trajectory traverses.

fuzzy.old.fcm.guess_centroids(k, dim=2, bounds=None, smart_guess=False)¶

Provide an initial guess for centroids.

if smart_guess is True, this function will attempt to ‘cheat’ and use hardcoded centroid positions. If more than k=4 smartly-guessed centroids are requested, it will panic and just return random centroids.

Otherwise, random centroids (within the bounds of the muller potential) are generated.

fuzzy.old.fcm.guess_centroids_smart(k)¶

A cheat function that makes good guesses for the centroids of the muller potential.

Values are hard-coded. If more than k=4 centroids are requested, this function returns None and it is up to the calling function to provide a fallback mechanism.

fuzzy.old.fcm.plot_centroids(centroids, marker_sizes=None)¶

Plot the centroids of a particular clustering scheme.

If marker_sizes is given, it will use this array as the sizes for the various centroids. This is useful for visualizing eigenvectors.

fuzzy.old.fcm.plot_eigens(centroids, vec, vals, desc)¶

Plot eigenvectors (one at a time).

fuzzy.old.fcm.plot_points(points)¶

Plot points.

fuzzy.old.fcm.plot_points_with_alpha(points, memberships)¶

Plot points and their memberships.

Points are colored based on the cluster in which it has the highest membership, and the alpha value is set to that membership value.

mullerforce Module¶

Propagating 2D dynamics on the muller potential using OpenMM.

Currently, we just put a harmonic restraint on the z coordinate, since OpenMM needs to work in 3D. This isn’t really a big deal, except that it affects the meaning of the temperature and kinetic energy. So take the meaning of those numbers with a grain of salt.

class fuzzy.old.mullerforce.MullerForce¶

OpenMM custom force for propagation on the Muller Potential. Also includes pure python evaluation of the potential energy surface so that you can do some plotting

AA = [-200, -100, -170, 15]¶
XX = [1, 0, -0.5, -1]¶
YY = [0, 0.5, 1.5, 1]¶
aa = [-1, -1, -6.5, 0.7]¶
bb = [0, 0, 11, 0.6]¶
cc = [-10, -10, -6.5, 0.7]¶
classmethod plot(ax=None, minx=-1.5, maxx=1.2, miny=-0.2, maxy=2, **kwargs)¶

Plot the Muller potential

classmethod potential(x, y)¶

Compute the potential at a given point x,y

strength = 0.5¶
fuzzy.old.mullerforce.get_default_bounds()¶

Get the bounds of the muller potential.

This can be useful for setting plot limits after additional data has been plotted, or these bounds can be used for generating test data.

test_gen Module¶

Testing various schemes for building a count matrix.

A count matrix is traditionally built from a series of state indices. With fuzzy clustering, however, we must build an equivalent matrix from ‘membership vectors’. This module tests various ways of doing this.

fuzzy.old.test_gen.main(func=<function outernorm at 0x5f52938>)¶

Test schemes.

fuzzy.old.test_gen.outer(v1, v2)¶

The outer product.

fuzzy.old.test_gen.outernorm(v1, v2, which='rows')¶

The outer product followed by a normalization.

which controls the axis of normalization and can be ‘rows’ or ‘columns’.

fuzzy.old.test_gen.putter(v1, v2)¶

The vectors stacked.
